node.title: Broadway Grosses Dip as Omicron Prompts Some Shows to Cancel
node.alt: Several Broadway shows have canceled all performances until after Christmas, including “Hamilton,” because of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
node.description: The surge in coronavirus cases comes at a tough time for the theater industry, which traditionally relies on the holiday season box office.
node.content: ["The surge in coronavirus cases is starting to take a real financial toll on Broadway, just as the industry is attempting to rebound from its lengthy shutdown.", "The Broadway League, a trade association, said on Tuesday that its theaters brought in $22.5 million last week. That\u2019s a 26 percent drop from the $30.5 million in tickets sold the previous week; in the week before Christmas in 2019, total grosses were $40.1 million.", "The drop in grosses is a reflection of the fact that multiple shows have canceled performances when positive coronavirus tests forced cast or crew members to quarantine and there were not enough understudies or replacement workers for the shows to continue.", "Last weekend, about one-third of all shows canceled some performances, and this week, multiple shows decided to postpone performances until after Christmas, including \u201cAin\u2019t Too Proud,\u201d \u201cAladdin,\u201d \u201cDear Evan Hansen,\u201d \u201cHadestown,\u201d \u201cHamilton,\u201d \u201cHarry Potter and the Cursed Child,\u201d \u201cThe Lion King, \u201cMJ\u201d and \u201cSkeleton Crew.\u201d Plus, \u201cTina\u201d canceled until Christmas night; \u201cJagged Little Pill\u201d closed entirely; and \u201cMrs. Doubtfire\u201d canceled Tuesday night.", "Attendance also dropped, given the cancellations: 184,227 people saw a Broadway show last week, down from 240,602 the previous week.", "The resulting revenue drop is a real concern for an industry where most shows, even before the pandemic, fail financially. But the damage is not evenly dispersed \u2014 some shows that stay open are benefiting by selling tickets to people scrambling for something to see after their first-choice show canceled. This year the Broadway League is releasing only aggregate weekly grosses rather than breaking them down for individual productions, so it is difficult to see exactly how the financial ramifications are unfolding.", "Five other shows cited the pandemic shutdown in deciding not to reopen this fall \u2014 the musicals \u201cFrozen,\u201d \u201cMean Girls\u201d and \u201cWest Side Story\u201d and the plays \u201cHangmen\u201d and \u201cWho\u2019s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?\u201d Two shows cited the ongoing pandemic in deciding to close for good after starting (or restarting) performances this fall, then pausing because of positive coronavirus tests in their companies: not only \u201cJagged Little Pill,\u201d which announced its closing Monday night, but also the play \u201cChicken & Biscuits,\u201d which closed last month.", "The current crisis is coming at the worst possible time for the industry, because the holiday season is traditionally the most lucrative time of year for Broadway, and many shows depend on the holidays to make up for softer periods.", "Charlotte St. Martin, the president of the Broadway League, said she does not envision the industry shutting down again, no matter how many individual shows have to pause. \u201cI do not imagine a shutdown by us, unless every show has people with Covid,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to keep as many people employed as we can.\u201d", "And New York Mayor Bill de Blasio, at a news conference on Tuesday, was similarly shutdown-averse. \u201cNo more shutdowns,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve been through them. They were devastating. We can\u2019t go through it again.\u201d"]
